Thank you everyone for replying to my question.  All of you
understood...and gave very helpful advice.  I even learned something
new.  Men=humans.  Anime men=gods.  I got that straight

P.S. Try reading some Yukio Mishima. He does a lot of delving into
men's psyches... sometimes to the point I want to scream "just get on
with the story!" (Thinking of "Confessions of a Mask" and "Forbidden
Colors," which I'm currently reading, but psychological exploration
seems to be one of his hallmarks in all his fiction... and he's
writing from a Japanese perspective, though again, it's actually
universal.)

completely OT...

Mishima was a pretty *interesting* guy.
I happen to be reading THE TEMPLE OF THE DAWN (isbn 0394466144) right
now because it centers on a character's rebirth in Thailand (a country
I am studying)

I would like to call attention to a lengthy passage in The
Temple...pages 169-174 which deals with the "Land of the Pomegranate"
<<< Miss B! (symbolism of this fruit is interesting here)

[scary quotes from The Land of the Pomegranate passages...]

page 170 "Don't you think it's true brotherly love to terminate life
while beautiful people are still young?"
Think Mishima's life o_O

page 171 "...there are only two roles for humans in this world: those
who remember and those who are remembered."
I'm thinking about the commercialized revival of the Shinsengumi and
the reexamination of the group by historians (by the way there are
many talks/lectures going on around Japan this year at museums etc
some are held at Shinsengumi club chapters too)

page 172 "The basic concept is memory, and in a manner of speaking,
memory is national policy"
The Land of the Pomegranates talks about beautiful and ugly people
(who worship the beautiful)...the worshippers remember the beautiful
people and the imaginative land is propelled by memory.  I'm thinking
about historical figures which are constantly resurrected/reincarnated
(Mishima talks about this too) would fit in the category of the
"beautiful"

***anyways the passages talks about errrr some very adult stuff so I'm
keeping it rated G but yeah Mishima has amazing insight into the human
psyche
